title: Forces from surfaces - person on escalator

content.question: A person standing on an escalator is not moving relative to the escalator steps. The escalator steps are moving up and to the right at constant velocity. Let the force that the escalator step exerts on the person’s feet be <math alttext="F sub feet" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>feet</mi></msub></math> and let the force that the person’s feet exert on the escalator step be <math alttext="F sub step" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>step</mi></msub></math>. Do these two forces have equal magnitude?

choices.label: No, because the person and step are moving to the right.
No, because the step exerts a force on the person greater than the person’s weight.
Yes, because the person and step move with constant velocity.
Yes, because the person and the step create an interacting force pair.

content.answer: Yes, because the person and the step create an interacting force pair.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
